body: The `DirectRunner` should reuse readers for some amount of time, and forever until they produce elements. #1128 fixes the current state to actually continue to read from a shard that ever returned false in an initial evaluation, but is not directly related to this change.
R: @dhalperi
LGTM. Will merge when green, but also feel free to get another committer to merge if I disappear into meeting world.

@amitsela 
PTAL

>  I believe the simple rule of thumb should be "readers should return as soon as they are able" + "runners may poll advance() in a loop for a certain period of time if it returned too fast" + "runners must tolerate sources that take a long time to start or advance, because real systems operate that way".

I like these. :+1:
LGTM
LGTM

Yes; I've ran `WindowedWordCount` on the `DataflowRunner` and set `--streaming`; the BigQuery table was loaded

After talking with @bjchambers and @robertwb, we decided to leave Python classes as STRING types until the Fn API allows us to represent classes in a generalized manner. I've updated the tests, code, and new documentation to reflect this.
I've addressed all outstanding feedback. Travis failures are flakes. PTAL @bjchambers

I actually think we don't need this:

https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0440/#exclusive-ordered-comparison

I think we can verify more than table was loaded.

There is big query io coder unbounded read tests. You can port the one line change and run the test 20 times easily.
The test will verify the output is expected, and also tests if it is flaky.

Even though this is just one line, it switches to new code path. And, bounded batch write sometimes doesn't work automatically in streaming.
Jenkins failure is a failure to connect to local JDBC, not related to this PR.

@rangadi I've addressed your comments, PTAL.

As a general comment on ROS - if runners are to relay on them, how can we have them run only on post commit ? maybe only run the ROS on a specific runner if it's/SDK's code changed ?
So for examples commits to Flink runner won't run ROS on Spark runner (and vice versa).
WDYT ?
Please close PR and re-open when this is ready.

I agree that sounds pretty nice. I think the infrastructure issues involve some real work. This might be a good discussion for the dev list. I don't have a ton of insight into the ways we can configure things like that. The merge bot in development might help.

Once workflow I use a lot (when I can) is to separate (1) human feedback from (2) quick machine feedback from (3) slow machine feedback. Humans do what they are good at - style, architecture, sanity checking - and quick machine feedback handles minutia. The slower feedback can often wait until I've decided to submit (or I can run it myself if my change is sensitive to it). I think this workflow would manifest as shrinking Jenkins and Travis to much less, while having mergebot do much more.

I'm afraid I'm no expert when it comes to testing/deployment infra. I just had a thought that seemed worth sharing.
I'll add this to my list of things that go in the Dev list

There does seem to be a real failure at https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_MavenVerify/3995/org.apache.beam$beam-runners-spark/testReport/junit/org.apache.beam.runners.spark.translation.streaming/ResumeFromCheckpointStreamingTest/org_apache_beam_runners_spark_translation_streaming_ResumeFromCheckpointStreamingTest/ where Kafka is binding to a port that is in use (maybe conflicting with a concurrent build or test case?)

```
kafka.common.KafkaException: Socket server failed to bind to localhost:36520: Address already in use.
    at kafka.network.Acceptor.openServerSocket(SocketServer.scala:260)
    at kafka.network.Acceptor.<init>(SocketServer.scala:205)
    at kafka.network.SocketServer.startup(SocketServer.scala:86)
    at kafka.server.KafkaServer.startup(KafkaServer.scala:99)
    at org.apache.beam.runners.spark.translation.streaming.utils.EmbeddedKafkaCluster.startBroker(EmbeddedKafkaCluster.java:125)
    at org.apache.beam.runners.spark.translation.streaming.utils.EmbeddedKafkaCluster.startup(EmbeddedKafkaCluster.java:115)
    at org.apache.beam.runners.spark.translation.streaming.ResumeFromCheckpointStreamingTest.init(ResumeFromCheckpointStreamingTest.java:90)
    at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
    at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:62)
    at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
    at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:498)
```
Yeah, my implementation of an embedded Kafka chooses a port randomly, this seems like purely bad luck.
Ping.
I've addressed previous concerns. @robertwb PTAL : )

Got it. Is it possible to bind the embedded Kafka to port `0` and then find out which it was assigned? I understand this might be a plumbing pain. I've run the following,

```
mvn integration-test -Plocal-runnable-on-service-tests -pl runners/spark -am
```

which surfaces a failure in `CombineTest.testSessionsCombineWithContext()`. Is this related to [BEAM-696](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-696)?

Travis is doing its usual ~50% green.

Overall, I prefer having a running test config with a failure to no actual tests running, and it is better for collaboration to get this in, so LGTM. I'll merge it and suggest to roll forwards with any further improvements and fixes.

Actually, could you rebase and maybe reword the first commit messages, then merge? The last commit seems like it could merge into the first nicely, and then the list in the first commit could be a little more readable as bullets or something.

I'll rebase, reword and then merge.
Yes the failing test is infamous [BEAM-696](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-696)

As for the Kafka port, it happened a couple of times since we've setup Jenkins, and that's less than different flaking services in some of our tests.
Adding to that the fact that I'm going towards relaying on ROS (and IT tests) for testing the runner, I don't see a point in investing there, unless this becomes a recurring pain.

BTW, you think I should remove the runner's batch tests ? relay on ROS from now on ?
I don't think the failure has anything to do with this PR but I'll kick Jenkins again just to be sure.
I'll merge for now, filed [BEAM-781](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-781) for removing the unit tests.
I think this is something we should bring back to the dev list since there isn't a clean solution either way and both have drawbacks.

R: @bjchambers if you have time, since it follows up your prior few reviews in this area
At this point, I don't think the approach of moving the deps around works quite right. I'll close this and open one that just fixes the typo and deps.
We should also do this on Jenkins.

This seems like something that `RunnableOnService` tests should have caught. If not, then your new test seems like it can definitely be runner independent.

What am I missing?

This test will likely be expanded to cover Apex runner specific things and I added it actually to investigate the issue with View.AsSingleton 

Discovery of the bug with side outputs was a side effect :-) The problem was that nothing was emitted with the main output tag, which the integration test did not catch: 

https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/apex-runner/sdks/java/core/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/transforms/ParDoTest.java#L710

```
    PAssert.that(outputs.get(mainOutputTag))
        .satisfies(ParDoTest.HasExpectedOutput
                   .forInput(inputs)
                   .andSideInputs(11, 222));
```

Actually, the one test failure I was getting in IntelliJ is because I just run all the SDK tests with the `DirectRunner`. But the test `ParDoTest.testRejectsSplittableDoFnByDefault` actually fails with the `DirectRunner`, and since it isn't a `NeedsRunner` test it won't run in our official test suite.

Nonetheless, I think it indicates a potential problem. Not necessarily blocking.

R: @kennknowles
Jenkins failure seems related to `gs` service issues.

Seems like it complains it can't find `org.apache.beam.sdk.io.BoundedReadFromUnboundedSource` referenced [here](https://github.com/amitsela/incubator-beam/blob/BEAM-658/runners/spark/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/spark/io/MicrobatchSource.java#L40).
Anybody got an idea why ?

Hmm. I checked out htis PR and ran `mvn clean verify -DskipTests` and build succeeded.

Trying again with `-Prelease` also set.
R: @amitsela

Was able to replicate with `-Prelease` set.

The problem is that `BoundedReadFromUnboundedSource` is package-private. That's a bug -- there's no reason to believe that only code inside of the `sdk.io` package should want to use this functionality. [Sent a PR](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/1145).
LGTM

CC: @tgroh

Ah, yes. This has bitten many runners so far (all of them, maybe?) when they are first written :-)

This should really be owned by `TestPipeline` or something around there, but it seems each runner needs to do it for now: You can see in `TestDataflowRunner`:

There is some counting of how many asserts should run: https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/google-cloud-dataflow-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/dataflow/testing/TestDataflowRunner.java#L181

And there is some checking that they all ran: https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/runners/google-cloud-dataflow-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/dataflow/testing/TestDataflowRunner.java#L188
Rebased and ready.
Agreed that the Jenkins failures are immaterial.
